DRIVE THROUGH VISIT WITH TEACHERS AT JHS

This week is Teacher Appreciation Week!!! Please consider sending our teachers an email, video, or message that highlights why you appreciate them!!! When I asked teachers what they wanted for Teacher Appreciation Week they said "We want to see our kids!!!" So please come out this Thursday, May 7 between 3:00 p.m. and 5:00 p.m. to JHS for a JHS Drive-in to say hello to teachers and show appreciation for our wonderful staff. They would love to see their students and share messages of encouragement to finish the year strong!! We will be out at the school's front loop as well as along the side between The Netz and Jackson High School so cars can pull through and loop around!! If you come, please adhere to social distancing guidelines and stay in your vehicles. We would love to see our students and our families on Thursday!!! Take care and stay healthy!!

Jeff KrackerPrincipal, Jackson High Schooljrk2jc@jackson.sparcc.org

Mackenzie Czekansky, JHS and JSA freshman was awarded a National Silver Medal in the 2020 Scholastic Art and Writing Awards.

This year, students in grades 7-12 submitted nearly 340,000 works of art and writing to the Scholastic Awards. Here is your press pass. We need everybody's help to continue telling the story of life and learning in the Jackson Local Schools. We still hope to produce our year-end edition of Polar Bear Pride and make regular posts on this page.

HERE'S HOW TO SUBMIT.
1. Email the photo(s) to me, Paula Blangger, at pmb1jc@jackson.sparcc.org
2. Include in the email
• a few details about what’s happening in the photo(s)
• names, school and grade level of people in the photo(s) from left to right

Don’t worry about writing a story. I’ll do that for us. Just blab to me about what is going on. And although it’s not necessary, feel free to gather quotes from kids or others involved. To get the conversation started with young people, I often ask questions such as: What do/did you like most/least about (whatever is going on)? What will you remember about this when you are much older? How has this made you a better thinker/learner/person? What was the scariest/hardest/most satisfying/most exciting thing about this?
